title: 110_hr3133
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Financial Literacy for Homeowners Act". The Congress acknowledges the impact of expanded access to credit on homeownership rates, but expresses concern about predatory lending practices that make homeownership more costly for vulnerable families. Borrowers with fair credit can access loans in the prime market, while those with poor credit turn to the subprime market with higher rates and fees. Predatory lending in the market involves unjustifiably high interest rates, excessive fees, and other unreasonable terms, particularly affecting minority neighborhoods and cash-poor homeowners. This practice strips away wealth accumulated over decades or a lifetime. The joint report by the Department of Housing and Urban Development and the Department of the Treasury urged Congress to adopt legislation to curb predatory home mortgage lending, restrict abusive terms on high-cost loans, improve consumer literacy and disclosures, and prohibit government-sponsored enterprises from purchasing loans with predatory features. The joint report recommended a four-point plan to address predatory lending, including improving consumer literacy and disclosures, disclosing credit scores to borrowers, and providing timely and accurate loan information. Government agencies are working to reduce high-pressure sales tactics and misleading practices by lenders. Predatory lending poses a threat to the efforts of nonprofit organizations working to improve distressed neighborhoods. More assistance is needed for borrowers with predatory loans, consumer education on home loan risks is crucial, and referrals to government agencies for help are essential. Grant program established for education and counseling on predatory lending. The Secretary of the Treasury may provide grants to States, local governments, and nonprofits for eligible anti-predatory lending activities. These activities include education programs to inform vulnerable consumers about predatory lending practices related to home loans. The Secretary of the Treasury may provide grants for anti-predatory lending activities, including counseling programs and referral services for homeowners and prospective homeowners to address fraudulent lending practices. The Secretary of the Treasury may provide grants for anti-predatory lending activities, including counseling programs and referral services for homeowners and prospective homeowners to address fraudulent lending practices. Eligible entities must submit an application for a grant, with a maximum amount of $1,000,000 per fiscal year. The Secretary will select applicants from States, local governments, and nonprofit organizations. States, local governments, and nonprofit organizations can apply for grants under this section, with the Secretary selecting recipients based on established criteria. SEC. 4. TOLL-FREE TELEPHONE NUMBER FOR PREDATORY LENDING COMPLAINTS.

The Secretary will establish a nationwide toll-free telephone number for consumer complaints about predatory lending practices related to home loans. The line will provide information, refer borrowers with predatory loans to appropriate agencies, and coordinate with State and nonprofit organizations to create a consumer resource database. Complaints and information will be handled by a live person at all times.

SEC. 5. PREDATORY LENDING ADVISORY COUNCIL. Established in the Department of the Treasury is a Predatory Lending Advisory Council (referred to as the "Council") to advise the Secretary on policies and issues regarding predatory and unscrupulous lending practices in home loans. The Council consists of 13 members appointed by the Secretary, including representatives of community-based organizations, State agency officials, and others involved in consumer protection. The Predatory Lending Advisory Council, established in the Department of the Treasury, consists of 13 members appointed by the Secretary. The Council includes representatives from community-based organizations, State agencies, private homeowners familiar with home loans, and the private real estate industry. Members serve two-year terms, with initial appointments split between one-year and two-year terms. They serve without compensation but receive travel expenses. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment process. The Predatory Lending Advisory Council, established by the Department of the Treasury, consists of 13 members appointed by the Secretary. The Council advises the Secretary on grant program criteria and toll-free telephone number operations. Meetings are called by the chairperson at least three times a year, with the authority to hold public hearings and receive testimony. The Predatory Lending Advisory Council advises the Secretary on prevention of predatory lending practices, coordinates activities with lending institutions, and conducts a study on default and foreclosure causes for home loans. The Council will submit a report with recommendations for consumer protection legislation within 12 months of its appointment. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. The term "home loan" under this Act refers to a loan secured by residential property, including home equity lines of credit and home improvement loans. The term "nonprofit organization" is defined as per the Cranston-Gonzalez National Affordable Housing Act. The term "predatory or unscrupulous lending practice" includes making loans solely based on home equity, without considering the borrower's ability to repay, and that are unaffordable, leading to difficulties in meeting mortgage payments or foreclosure. The term "predatory or unscrupulous lending practice" includes inducing borrowers to refinance repeatedly, charging additional fees, and engaging in fraud to conceal loan obligations from unsuspecting borrowers. The term "unit of general local government" refers to any city, town, township, parish, village, or other political subdivision of a State. Authorization of appropriations for carrying out the Act is set at $55,000,000 annually from 2008 to 2012, with specific allocations for different sections. The Secretary is authorized to issue regulations to implement the Act.
